title: Status of Framework Development
segmentation: I want to give you an update on the status of development of the common framework and if I stay status of development, I have to talk about past, present and future so it will describe.
What is developed over the past two years but also address some recent advancements that have been made and even a small look forward to what we can expect.
Now if you look to it.
The agenda I will sum up what were the initial arguments to actually come to a common framework and what were the building blocks of it.

Then we will get to the current status because the common framework has already been entered at me at least, most of it into UBL 2.1, so I will inform you on the status of that and also align give you a glimpse of how we have aligned that with other standardization developments that are ongoing within JS Wanan within UNC fact.

And then I will give you an update on more recent further developments that have been done in aligning the common framework with, let's say, new views that were provided by for example people by vicio by the Disquised project.
And finally, also getting back to the more traditional EDI messages which proved to be more important than we thought on before hand.
And then I will address also some issues to point to the needs of the common framework, 'cause if we cannot clarify why we need it, then what's the use of it all?
But first of all, which were the original building blocks to come to the common framework?
There have been many developments within EU funded projects which were often focused within specific sectors, so we have River information systems.
We have urban logistics.
We have the mega time vision.
We have intelligent cargo and vehicle to infrastructure communication.
We have dedicated programs and developments in the railway transportation sector.
And these are often communities which are not completely overlapping, and which sometimes have some difficulties understanding each other.

So the common framework was set up in order to take one abstraction level higher helicopter view on how actors in transport and logistics collaborate and exchange information, and the core concept is that we are speaking about transport services.

The Wolf Kong introduced my speech with talking about Jay's arms, and as you know, in Tele communication we're not bothering anymore about whether the cables are made of copper or of glass fiber or whatever.
Everything is built upon a concept of service and quality of service, and in that sense we are using a service more based on its.
Kualiti parameters, then about the way that it is actually implemented, and that's the same type of.
Let's say higher level abstract view that we want to achieve in the transport on the jestice sector.

I said I have to introduce the past a little bit and because not all of you may be up to date on the core concepts which are underlying the common framework, I have to introduce again a few items, but will try to keep that rather brief.
Now the common framework introduced role.
Rules.
What do I mean with stats?
If you go to support community, say and you access all the actors that appear in a port, then you can make a list of.
2030 different types of actors and it already becomes quite complex.
So in order to.
Creates a framework of collaboration and roles and data exchange that can apply to different settings.
We took the step of abstracting those holes so that means that the holes that we still maintain a common framework or fewer, but our one abstraction layer higher.
So what we see in this picture is in the center of it.
We have two important roles to logistic services clients and logistic services.

Provider who have a bit to be relationship and I as an example you could say that the logistic services client is the shipper like pork and gamble and a logistic service provider is for example a company like Shankar or DHL.
Of course we have consignor consignee that's order.
Basic and then on the right side of the diagram you have a transport regulator.
Now there are many transport regulators that we see.

You have food safety agencies, you have customs authorities you have maritime administrations, different authorities and regulators which are captured on the one term which is the transport regulator and then you have transportation network managers, which again can be several roles that you know from the practical fields and inland navigation waterway network authority.
The Port Authority Traffic Management Authority in the air transportation, even.
So you see that we are reducing the amount of holes to the absolute minimum in order to simplify, and in order to achieve concepts that apply to a wide range of settings.
I'm going to skip this one to save some time.
OK.
The second concept, which is part of the framework, is the process descriptions.

What are the processes that are part of the common framework at the bottom of this diagram you see the operational part of the process is so operational, planning and execution and completion of transport and registax operations on the top of the diagram you see process steps that more have to do with long term planning, and this is highly influenced by the logistics information model by JS1.
Now these processes and roles are connected to each other and there we see also the emergence of.
Traditional messages we call them information packages that facilitate communication between these roles.
Now you see from left to right for specific roles that have been isolated.
Here the logistic services client provider.
So those two are the beat to be parts transport, regulator and transportation Network manager from top to bottom.
You see the planning and execution stages as far as the operational part is concerned and you see.
Different three letter abbreviations that's identify communications between these roles, and I want to do that quickly by giving an example.
Over here we have the so called transport service description.

Can you imagine that Shanker rail operator publishes electronically the rail services that they are offering on the market, including all relevant details relating to time, behavior, schedules, pricing if needed at that moment?
Environmental footprint.
Answer On and Shank.
It could actually publish that information towards users of such services.
Then at a certain time, the use of such services which could be DHL's and integrate of services.
Would like to come to a contractual agreement with Shanker about using that service for specific shipment.
And for that purpose it exchanges information between each other, which is called the tap.
The transport execution plan.
This is harder compatible with what you know from the practical fields, bookings, booking confirmations, transport instructions and so on.
Then if you go further down, my mouse does not really respond.

You see that during execution this transport service provider can report status back to its user status about the execution of that service, which is done reported by way of a transport execution status.

Now we will not go further into detail concerning the time, but what is relevant at this moment is that this concept of elementary communications between the roles is also extended towards communications with the administrations.

So you see that there is also a communication called Seeress common repository schema, solely a common regulatory schema which is communicated from a logistic service provider towards a transport regulator, which can be a customs authority.
Or another authority and.
The common regulatory schema intends to be 1 standard message which can be used for all types of compliance reporting to authorities.
You see at the bottom also the SDM, the security data message which was introduced in the smart city, and projects that we had our final meeting yesterday.
In the final Advisory Board meeting.
And then at the end you see also communications between providers of services like batch operator and the transportation Network Manager.

For example, a waterway authority reporting about certain bottlenecks in the River Network or reporting on the plants arrival of barges towards in and terminals which can make use of the transport operation status and the transport network status.

Now, these messages that were just introduced as small three letter abbreviations, of course are more extensive than that, and we are going to process of having those messages incorporated in a standardization development and the current status is.
Is that five or six of the common framework messages are actually part of UBL 2.1.
Which is currently being reviewed and which will be launched early next year.
Now, how is this being situated on in comparison with other standardization developments now I have isolated two other developments here which is on the one hand the logistics information model.
Excuse me, the logistics interoperability model from JS one and you won't see facts.
Now concerning James one.
It is so that we are aligning our work in the development of these common framework messages continuously with the work that is ongoing in JS one.
And we are maintaining a mapping between the messages in the common framework and the messages as they are known within JS One.
That means that if there are anybody who is using systems that can communicate with the rest of the world through the messages that JS one prescribes, then that can be mapped.
What's common framework Max messages and as such, is completely interoperable with the rest of the common framework compliant community.
Another development, which is of course already taking place for a long, long, long time.
Yes UNC facts which started off with the original edifact messages.
Now UNC fact is very well known for its so called Core Components library and core components are the basic building blocks of data which are composed together to form electronic messages.
Now these core components that UNC Fact is introducing are the same core components as what UBL is using when composing messages.
This is not a one on one relation, which I also introduced it in the slide becausw.
JPL sometimes is advancing more speedily than UNC fact and can come to the conclusion that certain core components are needed which are not yet in the library, so that is done.
It kind of revision reviewing process that takes place once in awhile, but in essence the core components that UBL is using and the basic core components library from.
You won't see fact is coordinated with each other and that means that all the common framework messages are built using core components that basically either now or after.
If you are being part of UNC.

Then within UNC factor some new development going on with the new technical committee that is creating messages to support Co modality and we are establishing a liaison between the common framework development and UNC facts to make sure that we are trying to influence that process and make sure that those message structures are as much as possible.
Alliance and we will come back to the traditional Edifact world later on in my purse.
Station.
Now, what is the current status of the common framework within JPL?
Asset, there has been a second public review which was taking place until end of September.
And there was a list of issues that was reviewed that was launched by reviewers and this is currently being processed.

The messages that are included are the transport service description, the transfer execution plan and the transport execution status which I introduced earlier on in this presentation, but also the goods item at Tenner Airy, which is an additional message to, let's say, provide more transparency in the routes that goods are following and also in the transport operation status now asset.
There will be an expected final release of U BL2 point one with these messages included early next year.
And I listed the URL's where you can find more.
About that now, this is not a final situation.

There will be 1/3 or development of the common framework and what is taking place is the common framework is being exposed to comparisons with other developments and other typical industry situations and based on that validation takes place one of those validations is common framework versus purple.
But Paul is also in the European initiative to enable E invoicing and the ordering between the European Community and providers of all kinds of products.
And of course there's a little overlap between the two initiatives.
'cause part of the common framework is when you are booking transport services, so booking transport services can of course be compared to ordering.

Products and in that area that is an alignment taking place between the relevant messages in that area within purple and within a common framework, and a common demonstration is actually planned as part of the phrase project.
Another validation which is taking place is being done as part of the disk wise project.
Disk wise is one of the EBS on pilot projects large launched by DG Enterprise and within that project we are validating the common framework based on.

Industry based pilots in which typical applications of the common framework are being tested out and it is being evaluated whether the common framework is sufficiently matured in order to support those situations, and one of them is taking place in Florida's in which the common framework is also used to support customs communications and we are at that point comparing the common framework with the VCO data model in detail and to see whether there are.
Any overlaps or any additions to the common framework that needs to be done?
And a second validation is taking place within Poland.

Where the typical application is being implemented related to consolidation of cargo flows based on the efficient consumer response working group and also there we are validating whether the common setup of the common framework is able to support such.
Applications.

Now there's another extension, or I would say more validation of the common framework which is taking place As for now as already mentioned in other places, to visit project that is being funded by within FP 7 and coordinated by DG Research called Conscious Consist stands for Collaborative Information Services for container management.
And there we are really communicating with very traditional.
Community system environments and a lot of it is fact based messages will pop up over there and you can think about message escalated to the container.
Messages like the coupon, an quarian Swan but also other messages that relate to movement of vessels in the transportation and so on.
And at the first step we identified which are all the relevant messages that are taking place in order to improve better planning and visibility in such operations.
And you can actually map that fairly well by common framework messages.
So what we are currently also doing is mapping those traditional edifact messages to what their counterparts within the common framework would be.
So that means that common framework will really be compliant with a very traditional world of the old edifact messages, which still makes out a lot of what's happening today.
And then the final extension with this, which is a look into the future, is remaining activity that is taking place as part of the disk wise projects.
Within this quiet we are comparing the common framework also with work that has been done in order EPS and pilots.

Such pilots are taking place in a variety of branches like the textile branch, automotive and the new project is being started up in the ARCO food sector and that is very typical to compare this big cause this quiet as a EBS and project is a rather strange phenomenon in this list 'cause all the other EBS and projects really have to do with the product oriented supply chain.
While this quiet is focusing on the transport and logistics services and you can actually see how those two can be merged together.
So that you could enable very easy planning and execution of supply chains where availability of products and logistic services are combined in order to organize delivery processes.
But I said that is a view into the future.
Now what is now the use of this common framework?
What is it bringing us which is not possible without an important part is done benefits.
We have been working a lot on.
Supply chain operations globally between Asia and Europe, and to see how can you actually improve such operations by better planning and visibility.

Smart salmon integrity where few of the projects that have been looking into detail to those operations that we tried to quantify what kind of benefits you could reach and what is quite clear is you should try to offer.
I see T services that are really competitively priced.
Otherwise, it's not possible to outweigh the benefits that you can reach on a short term.
Now, in order to get highly competitive ICT services.
Sorry for the switching of the slides.
We need to create economies of scale.
These things are only so cheap because they are sold in such huge quantities.
Now if we want to create economies of scale we need to.

Leave the time of stovepipe architectures and really have a market for interoperable components so that companies can specialize on specific components where they are best AT and creating economies of scale and creating components and services that are cheaper to use and so we are moving from a time when we have.
They closed systems into a time when components are.
Enter operating with each other and can be exchanged and conscious is 1 project.
That is Maya is wrong project that is doing that.

Another project which is taking that even one step further is the ikago projects where you will have a very dynamic collaboration between individual components that are identifying finding each other on the fly through the Internet and which are committing each other towards collaboration.
And that is maybe the topic that also my ex colleague.
Apollo finally can talk a little bit about and that's closest my presentation for today, thanks.
